titleInfo.title: T.M. DeMoss & Sons and the Berry Wholesale Drug Company

mods.abstract: View showing businesses T. M. DeMoss & Sons and the Berry Wholesale Drug Co. on Second Avenue. A Mason-Dixon Line shipping truck is parked near the shipping and receiving area for Berry Wholesale Drug Co. The door on one of the two Ford vans in front of the storefront has the name, slogan, and phone number for Berry Wholesale Drug Co. is visible on the door of one of the Ford vans. The windows are open in some of the buildings, and the word “Fire” appears in several of the second-story windows. The Hooper building has an inset stone with the name and date of construction, and the T. M. DeMoss & Sons building has a parapet with the date of construction. A portion of the building and sign for American Paper & Twine Co. is visible on the right.

The Hooper Building, located at 128-130 Second Avenue, was a three-story, commercial-style brick building constructed in 1924 by John M. Hooper. Starting in 1908, the Hooper Grocery Company began leasing the buildings at 129, 130, and 131 Second Avenue as their headquarters. The business was formerly located at 135 Second Avenue and moved due to the need to expand. A fire in October of 1923 amounted to $325,000 of damage to the business and other buildings surrounding it. The company was able to move back to the building in 1924. Significant alterations were made to the building over the years, with much of it demolished in 1994. The T.M. DeMoss & Sons building, located at 126 Second Avenue, was a three-story, Italianate style building constructed in 1879. A central parapet on the building is dated 1879. Heavy brackets support the cornice. The center bay of the three bays projects out and with brick corbelling on the second and third story. The arched second-story and third-story windows above the central bay each have a keystone accompanied by natural stones. T.M. DeMoss & Sons moved into the building in 1938.
